Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-08T18:14:16+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-26
  • City: W SACRAMENTO
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 26, 2023, eight (8) 1-gallon containers of UN1219 were crushed in transit and released approximately four (4) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Patriot Environmental Services (PES) to remediate the impacted site. PES personnel collected the eight (8) damaged pails of UN1219 and containerized them in one (1) 55-gallon drum. Crews then deployed granular absorbents and worked them in using hand tools. All UN1219 impacted material was collected and containerized in two (2) 55-gallon drums for disposal by R+L.

  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 25, 2023, four (4) one-gallon pails of UN1263 were damaged during transit and released approximately two (2) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Eastern Environmental Management (EEM) to remediate the impacted site. EEM personnel collected four (4) damaged one-gallon pails of UN1263 for disposal. Crews then utilized a pressure washer to alleviate staining to the extent practicable. All UN1263 impacted material and rinsate were collected and containerized in two (2) 55-gallon drums for disposal by R+L.

item.title: Report E-2023110083
item.description:
Report E-2023110083

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-08T18:14:16+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-25
  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 25, 2023, two (2) 5-gallon pails of UN1866 were crushed in transit and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer floor, tires, and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. TLE personnel collected two (2) damaged 5-gallon pails of UN1866 for disposal. Crews then deployed granular absorbent to the impacted trailer floor and pavement beneath trailer and worked them in utilizing hand tools. Once collected, TLE personnel utilized a degreasing agent with absorbent pads to collect any residual product on trailer floor, trailer tires and pavement. All undamaged freight was re-stacked and secured for normal transport. All UN1866 impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 85-gallon drum and two (2) 35-gallon drums and RLC personnel took possession of the waste.

R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the isobutyl acetate-impacted dock floor and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for terminal disposal.

  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Hazmat went out for delivery on a van. Package was brought back due to puncture in the top section of the package where Hazmat material was released. Hazmat was isolated and pulled from vehicle for inspection where it was discovered the package lost 2 quarts of liquid. DescribePack: Package had a small puncture that formed a slit on the top of the jerrican next to the fill cap. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Package was called into station by driver about release and was segregated from other packages till brought back to station for proper removal. Driver covered Hazmat in a non-leak wrap.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Description: On October 24, 2023, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN1263 was damaged during loading and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Marion Environmental (ME) to remediate the impacted site. Crews collected the one (1) damaged 5-gallon pail and placed it in one (1) 30-gallon drum for transport to the local RLC terminal to be moved to the facilities waste consolidation area. ME personnel utilized absorbent pads to remove free product from the trailer floor and deployed granular absorbents to collect any residual product. All paint impacted material was collected in one (1) poly trash bag and ME took possession of the waste.

R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews collected the damaged drum and placed in in one (1) 85-gallon over pack. FCE personnel utilized hand tools to collect all granular absorbents applied by RLC. All ammonium hydroxide impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum and both drums were added to RLC waste stream for disposal.

item.description:
Report E-2023110034

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-07T18:15:22+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-19
  • City: KANSAS CITY
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 19, 2023, ten (10) 5-gallon bladders of UN3267 were punctured by a forklift and released approximately seven (7) gallons of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Environmental Works, Inc. (EWI) to remediate the impacted site. EWI personnel neutralized and collected the released product with citric acid, and they repeated this process until no corrosive liquid remained and the surface had a neutral pH. Crews cut-up the impacted pallet with hand tools. All neutralized product, the cut-up pallet, the ten (10) damaged bladders, and cleanup debris were collected and containerized into three (3) 55-gallon poly drums that were staged in the terminal's waste holding room.

  • Description: On October 19, 2023, one (1) 55-gallon drum of printing ink was impacted by a skid and released approximately three (3) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from E3/OMI (E3) to remediate the impacted site. . E3 personnel deployed granular absorbents to the printing ink-impacted floor and swept them in with hand tools. They cut up the impacted pallet and all spent absorbents and waste were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum and one (1) 85-gallon over pack for transport and disposal.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LSX experienced a UN2810 Durez 04347A Liquid One Step Phenolic Resin release from a 55-gallon metal drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.5-gallons of product released to a 1’ x 1’ area of the concrete dock floor due to a forklift puncture. The damaged drum was placed into an 85-gallon poly overpack. Absorbents were then deployed and worked into the impacted area. All impacted absorbents and cleanup debris were containerized into a 5-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: It was reported that due to a weeping weld 1 cup of material has been released onto the concrete floor, a contractor was required for the transfer of the product. It was determined that the tote could not be repaired and the product will need to be transferred. There was 350 Gallons of product in the leaking tote. All impacted surfaces were wiped down with water and the 1 cup of material released was absorbed into pads and containerized. The material remaining in the damaged tote was transferred to two new totes and they will continue to the destination. Terminal staff advised that the leaking steel tote will be returned to the shipper. (1) 5G DF - Impacted pads was created for waste and was left for the terminal to manage.

  • Description: Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.5-gallons of UN3082 "Elco 105" was released to a 4’ x 4’ area of the concrete dock floor due to a puncture caused by other freight. The product was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one for shipment to continue on. The impacted area was cleaned with absorbents. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with all cleanup debris into a cubic yard box and a 30-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023100912
item.description:
Report E-2023100912

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-06T09:12:13+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-19
  • City: MATTESON
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 19, 2023, one (1) 330-gallon tote of UN2014 was damaged in transit and released approximately 275-gallons of product to the trailer floor and concrete beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews utilized hand tools to collect and containerize all free-standing product and previously deployed absorbents from the trailer floor into five (5) 55-gallon open top drums. HCE personnel utilized a forklift to perform a gravity transfer of the remaining UN2014 in the tote into one (1) additional 55-gallon open top drum. All UN2014-impacted materials were collected and containerized into one (1) additional 55-gallon drum for transport and disposal. The impacted wood pallets were staged on site along with the seven (7) previously generated 55-gallon drums for further management.

item.title: Report E-2023100911
item.description:
Report E-2023100911

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-06T09:12:13+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-18
  • City: MONTEBELLO
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 18, 2023, one (1) 55-gallon drum of printing ink was punctured while in transit and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from GrayMar Environmental (GE) to remediate the impacted site. GE personnel deployed granular absorbent to the trailer floor and worked them in with hand tools, utilizing a degreasing agent with absorbent wipes to collect any residual product. The crew collected and containerized the damaged 55-gallon drum in one (1) 65-gallon overpack drum. All printing ink impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum and RLC personnel took possession of the waste.

The crews deployed granular absorbents to the released material and swept them in using hand tools. E3 personnel containerized all UN1263-impacted absorbents into one (1) 55-gallon drum for future disposal.

The drums were corroded, with the paint being clearly corroded and reaching into the layer of metal. The corrosion has caused the caps to unseal from the container and an odor, although not strong, was emanating from the damaged drums. It was confirmed 10oz spilled onto the tops of 2 of the drums. Two DM of waste were created, 2-85 gal overpack containing an impacted drum, both were left staged onsite for the terminal to manage.

  • Description: 1. X-2023100506 SequenceEvent: The package was discovered leaking on a trailer during the sort. Upon discovering that it was a damaged hazardous material, the package was left at our stations damage staging area and moved to the hazmat cage for further processing. DescribePack: A loose cap on the bottle leaked corrosive liquid throughout the package. The liquid damaged the exterior of the box as well. DurationRel: 3 and MitigateEffect: The items where placed upright so there would be no more spillage of corrosive liquid. The package was also isolated so as to not be breathed in by the package handlers. 2. X-2023100507 SequenceEvent: The package was discovered leaking on a trailer during the sort. Upon determining that it was a damaged hazmat, the package was left at our stations damage staging area and moved to the hazmat cage for further processing. DescribePack: A loose cap on the bottle leaked some of the corrosive liquid throughout the package. DurationRel: 3 and MitigateEffect: The items where placed upright so there would be no more spillage, and the caps were secured and checked on the undamaged bottles. 3. X-2023100508 SequenceEvent: The package was discovered leaking during the sort. Upon discovery that it was a hazardous material, the package was left at our stations damage staging area and moved to the hazmat cage for further processing. DescribePack: A loose cap leaked corrosive liquid throughout the package; the exterior of the box was corroded by the hazardous material as well. DurationRel: 3 and MitigateEffect: The items where placed upright so there would be no more spillage. The package was also isolated to prevent inhalation of toxic fumes.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: During sort package found leaking wet, discolored and strong chem smell. All signs indicate possible Hazard material. Inspection confirmed inner contents were cool chlorinating liquid and SDS items are considered hazardous. Bottles were individually wrapped but no partition used or packing to protect . DescribePack: Package did not have hazmat decals to indicate hazard shipping, did not have directional arrows which would have indicated top/bottom. inner packaging did not include partitions, liners. top/cap protectors. Outer box too big which led to shifting, as a result inner bottles were able to flip over and became bent. Leak from inner bottles caused outer box to fail DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Once identified, package was separated from other sort and placed in a hazmat bag and bin

item.title: Report X-2023100331
item.description:
Report X-2023100331

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-08T18:14:16+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-21
  • City: COCOA
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Driver gave 2 different accounts of the incident to QA and P&D. Initially, driver said that it fell out of his truck, but not while he was at a delivery stop or a pickup stop and he couldn't remember where it happened. He said that someone helped him hose down the liquid when they read that the material was called "Dishmachine Detergent." The driver gave the empty drum to QA and the inside of his truck was visible with pickups on the floor of the truck at that time. There were no additional damages from that Work Area. The following day, P&D was told that the spill occurred inside the delivery truck and that "they had hosed it down", but did not say when or where the spill occurred nor did they say who helped the driver clean up the truck since the Hazmat had been the only damaged package to return to the station. Only the empty drum was brought back, no cleanup material. DescribePack: Drum is scuffed and covered in sandy dirt. The lid appears to have come open partially or partially put back on after coming off. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Driver said someone helped him "hose it down", but not who or where or what was done with the cleanup material if any was used. Empty drum was brought back to the station.

DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: PPE donned, all spillage absorbed, and ventilation used.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Automotive fuel pump with gasoline still inside was packed inside a plastic bag and carton with no packing material. Upon arrival the pkg was found with a 2" puncture in one side panel due to improper loading and it had a strong odor of gasoline coming from it. The pkg was placed on conveyor and sent to QA where it was later taken to the HMPA for inspection and reporting. Inspection found the protective plastic bag the fuel pump was in was wet and several small droplets marks were found inside the carton. DescribePack: 1 x 1 automotive fuel pump with gasoline still in mechanism leaked creating a strong odor of gasoline. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Nothing. After discovery by this authorized Hazmat personnel the pkg was placed in a lined Hazmat bin to await disposition after reporting.

DescribePack: The sealant on 3/4 of the bottles inside the package looks like they corroded and caused seal to break and hazmat liquid to slowly leak out. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Absorbent was used to stop spread of leak. item.title: Report X-2023100252
item.description:
Report X-2023100252

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-08T18:14:16+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-22
  • City: WILLINGTON
  • State: CT
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Improperly marked pkg made its way to the destination without being entered in the Hazmat Acceptance Process (HAP). The destination station improperly failed the pkg in HAP and improperly attempted to return the pkg to the shipper. Destination station did not use the required DOT-Special Permit nor did they provide the required documentation for an Unprocessed Hazmat pkg being returned. Shipper provided incorrectly filled out Hazmat Certification and OP-900LL Hazmat tags. Number and Type Packaging is not acceptable, Technical Name is the same as the Number and Type Packaging. Pkg has a Ltd Qty diamond printed on it indicating the pkg could have shipped as such rather than fully regulated. Contents leaked wetting and staining the contents and carton. Due to the time and distance the pkg has travelled it is unknown how long the inner containers leaked. DescribePack: Loose caps on 2 x 1.3 L plastic bottles. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Pkg was kept upright. Once in the possession of personnel responsible for Hazmat damages/compliance, HAP the pkg was placed in a lined Hazmat salvage pail to await disposition after reporting.

item.title: Report X-2023100386
item.description:

  • City: MINNEAPOLIS

  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: PACKAGE WAS BROUGHT TO THE DMP AROUND 1:30 AM, FROM DOOR 33 ON THE UNLOAD, BY THE RESPONDER. IN THE DMP, PACKAGE WAS OPENED AND FOUND TO CONTAIN, THREE, 1 GALLON PLASTIC BOTTLES OF ALPHA 90 IA FLUX, BEING SHIPPED AS A CORROSIVE HAZ-MAT PACKAGE, (UN3284, CORROSIVE LIQUID, ACIDIC, INORGANIC, N.O.S. (HYDROCHLORIC ACID, ZINC CHLORIDE), 8, II, 1 FIBERBOARD BOX X3 GALLONS). THE CAPS ON TWO OF THE THREE BOTTLES, WHERE LOOSE, WHICH ALLOWED A LARGE AMOUNT OF THE ACID TO LEAK FROM BOTH BOTTLES WITH LOOSE CAPS. ALL PRODUCT WAS PROCESSED THROUGH THE DMP, ALONG WITH CARBOARD FROM SEVERAL OTHER BOXES WHICH WHERE AROUND THE LEAKING PACKAGE.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: FRA was inspecting cars a spotted residue on the side of CBTX 735329 opened the combination housing. Inside the housing found the liquid valve to be seeping at the base of the valve where it threads into the tank car. . Marathon Petroleum sent out there emergency responder SRS to remove the valve. Once the valve had been removed and visually inspected lack of thread sealant was deemed the reason why the valve was leaking. CBTX 735329 was then set out on the Rip track so it can have a certified leak test preformed.

item.title: Report E-2023100408
item.description:
Report E-2023100408

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-04T06:23:51+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-30
  • City: Selma
  • State: VA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX Transportation
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 9/30/23, at 2104, personnel in the CSXT Clifton Forge yard reported NATX400224, a loaded tank car of Anhydrous Ammonia, was suspected to leaking. The car was isolated and the shipper, Advansix, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 2023-10-01-00001). HEPACO, a CSXT emergency response contractor, as well as a CSXT Manager of Hazardous Materials, were dispatched to the scene and found product leaking through the pressure relief valve. CSX and contractor personnel contained the release with application of an emergency capping kit until such time that the contents of the leaking car were transloaded into tank car NATX400291. Additionally, response personnel utilized a highway transport truck to unload approximately 4,000 liquid gallons of product that could not be safely loaded into the NATX 400291 due to volumetric outage constraints. Because the leaking car was not equipped with a gauging device, response personnel were unable to determine the specific reason why the identified calf car could not accept the entire load; however, it is suspected that the NATX 400224 was originally overloaded prior to the pressure relief device failure. Upon completion of the product transload, response personnel purged the leaking car to clean/empty status. All issues identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative (Christian Beale 804-731-8124). While the car was suspected to be overloaded, the pressure relief device continued to leak for the duration of the unloading process- even at acceptable load volume and pressure. Because of the this, the pressure relief device was identified as non-conforming and an AAR form QA 7.1 was filed.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 9/9/2023 at approximately 1430, Dangerous Good Administration received a call from Employee 658069 at the hub facility in Memphis, reporting a spill incident, involving an undeclared corrosive liquid. The shipment consists of 1 fiberboard box conaining six 64oz bottles of Clobber drain cleaner. Per an online safety data safety, the shipment contained concentrated sulfuric acid and is classifed as UN 1830. Three of the bottles spilled from the package resulting in sizable spill and contaminating an estimated 30 packages. A vendor was called in the contain the spill. The affected shipments have been handles accrodingly. Further investigation revealed the spilled package was not declared as dangerous goods, in compliance with IATA Regulations. The shipment is places in a salvage drum and is being held, pending an investigation by the FAA.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Manager called me on the radio informing their was a damage with paint spilling out of it on the belt. Manager quickly put the damaged box into a non-haz bag and then we put the damaged package into a lined bin. DescribePack: So the package does have a hole towards the top corner seam of the package but it is unclear if that is what caused the spill inside the package. There was however a lot of room for the cans of paint to move around in the box. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: As stated before, the damaged package was immediately placed into a non-haz bag and placed into a lined bin after that. There was some spilled areas where the package handlers were loading so those areas were wiped down or soaked up with absorbent pads.

  • Description: PROX 12217 was found by a carmen to be leaking from the bottom of the tank during an outbound inspection. After investigation by BNSF Hazmat, it was determined that the leak was coming from the jacket, indicating a tank failure somewhere under the jacket. Approximately 50 gallons were recovered from containment pools. The car was moved to a siding after containment measures were put into place. The car was then transloaded into poly tanks while awaiting empty cars to arrive. The poly tanks were then transferred into two separate tank cars due to the smaller capacities than the original tank car.

  • Description: SHQX 12053 was found to be leaking from the top of the car during an FRA inspection. Upon investigation by BNSF HazMat, the leak was noted as coming from the manway. The swing bolts were tool tight, however after opening the manway lid, the gasket was noted to be in bad condition along with a pinching of the gasket at the leak origin. The manway gasket was replaced and the swing bolts were tool-tightened.

The swing bolts were tool-tight, however after opening the manway lid, it was noted that the manway gasket was missing. A new manway gasket was installed and the swing bolts tool-tightened. The car was cleaned and release into transportation.

item.title: Report X-2023090230
item.description:
Report X-2023090230

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-09T00:32:26+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-30
  • City: FORT WORTH
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Pkg Info ( TRK NBR=773245948314 PKG TYPE=Package (box/drum/jerrican/composite) PHY STATE=Liquid TRANSPORTATION PHASE=In Transit ) Commodity Info ( UNDG NBR=1824 CLASS=80 PSN TEXT=Sodium hydroxide solution PKG GRP=III SPILLED QTY=0 CONTAINER CAPACITY=1 CONTAINER UOM=Liquid - Liter MATERIAL CONSTRUCTION=C - Plastic NUMBER IN SHIPMENT=1 NUMBER FAILED=0 INNER PKG TYPE=1 - Bottle TOTAL AMT IN EACH CONTAINER=1 TOTAL UOM=Liquid - Liter )Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 147179 at the ramp facility in Fort Worth, reporting an undeclared corrosive spill on 8/30/2023 at approximately 0130. The shipment consists of one fiberboard box containing multiple items, including 3 bottles of concentrated hydrogen peroxide and 1 bottle of cleaner, both of which are classifed as fully regulated corrosive material. One of the bottles hydrogen peroxide spilled for an unknown reason, resulting in the outer package falling part. The shipment was not prepared in accordance with IATA regulations, being void of the required markings, labeling, packaging, and paperwork. One employee was affected and was treated at a first aid station. The shipment is being held, pending an FAA investigation.

item.title: Report X-2023090170
item.description:
Report X-2023090170

  • City: MIAMI
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Package was brought to the attention of the spill clean up specialist at our station location in Miami Florida when staining was seen indicating leaking inside the package. Package was found during the PM sort operations and was labeled as a UN 1993 Flammable Liquid n.o.s and Dry Ice. Package consisted of a fibreboard box overpack. Inside the fibreboard box was a Styrofoam box lined with a moisture barrier containing 3 jerricans of liquid commodity and 10 KG of dry ice. Inspection found the cap on one of the jerricans was loose and allowed for an estimated 1 liter of product to leak. It was instructed for liquid commodity placed in salvage drum to contain leak and dry ice to be removed. Consignee contacted for package retrieval.

item.title: Report X-2023090161
item.description:
Report X-2023090161

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-09T00:32:26+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-31
  • City: Harahan
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On August 31, 2023, FRA hazmat Inspector observed liquid dripping down the sides of railcar UTLX 95658 (L / UN 3082, Environmentally hazardous Substance, Liquid, N.O.S) while inspecting a track at CN Mays Yard. CN Contractor responded and observed liquid leaking down the sides of the railcar and dripping onto the ground in several locations. Upon closer inspection, the manway bolts were found to be tool tight but still allowed product to leak. The manway was opened so the gasket could be checked. The gasket was determined to be heavily worn and deteriorated. The gasket was replaced. The manway was resecured. The exterior of the railcar was decontaminated. The railcar was released onto destination.

item.title: Report X-2023090160
item.description:
Report X-2023090160

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-09T00:32:26+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-23
  • City: BATON ROUGE
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On August 23, 2023, CN Transportation crews reported a strong odor near RCRX 2119 while switching in CN Baton Rouge Yard. The railcar was isolated. All required notifications were made. CN Response contractor responded and upon arrival smelled an odor around the railcar. Upon closer investigation, the cause of the release was determined to be 3 of the 4 liquid line blind flange bolts were missing and all 4 of the vapor valve blind flange bolts were found to be less than tool tight. The missing bolts were found on the pressure plate of the tank car. The missing bolts were reinstalled, and the loose bolts were tightened which stopped the release. The exterior of the railcar was decontaminated, and the railcar was released and allowed to continue onto destination.

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Package was brough to the attention of the spill office located at out Oakland Hub location when it was seen package was leaking what appeared to be a gray paint on to the belts during sort operations. Package was packed in a fibreboard box without DG markings. There did appear to be old labels torn off the box before transport. Inspection of contents found a Rust*oleum Epoxy Shield 2 part garage floor coating kit. SDS of product indicated product is regulated for travel on aircraft. There was no moisture barrier in the box or positive closure on the cans. Brown paper was used for dunnage. Paper work in the package indicated shipment should have been offered for travel with FedEx Ground. Package placed in a steel salvage drum and held for FAA investigation.

  • Description: The TILX 730722 was found on 8/16/23 in the Tacoma Railyard with wetness on the tank car jacket by yard personnel. The car was isolated and notifications were made. BNSF Hazmat contractor responded and found the manway seal in place, however the swing bolts were less than tool tight and contributed to a release of fuel through the manway sealing area. Responders inspected and cleaned the gasket and resecured the manway lid. Degreaser and rags were used to clean residue from the tank car jacket. A small amount of impacted soil was removed. Loss estimate is based upon observations made by contract responders.

Consignee was contacted to inform customer of the damaged package and inquire for disposition.

  • Description: On August 14, CN Transportation crews observed liquid dripping down the sides on UTLX 125075. The railcar was isolated and all required notifications were made. CN response contractor responded to the site. Upon approaching the railcar, liquid was observed streaming down the sides of the railcar and pooling on the ground below the railcar. Under closer inspection, liquid was observed coming from the liquid eduction line. Attempts were made to tighten the cap and were unsuccessful. The pressure was relieved which stopped the leak. The liquid eduction cap was again attempted to be tightened again; 7 additional turns were achieved. The cap was removed to check if a gasket was installed. No gasket was observed. A gasket was installed in the liquid eduction cap and teflon tape was applied to the threads. The liquid eduction cap was properly installed. The exterior of the railcar was decontaminated. The railcar was released onto destination.

  • City: PORTLAND
  • State: OR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: BNSF RAILWAY COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: ODOT Hazmat Inspector C. Kuenzi identified the SHQX 50612 as leaking vapor in the protective housing during an inspection at the PTRC - Lakeyard. The car was isolated by PTRC employees and BNSF dispatched contract responders to inspect the car. The responders found the vapor valve plug to be less than tool tight, easily moved by hand and the valve to be partially open. The valve was fully closed and the leak was mitigated. The plug was removed, inspected and had teflon tape applied. The car was fully secured and inspected, then released back into transportation. All released LPG dissipated and no clean up was necessary. Estimated release volumes are only based upon a best estimate as observed by responders.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package arrived to our station already damaged/leaking. Pkg was damaged during transit. Pkg was discovered while being unloaded and was taken to our QA team. DescribePack: The lids on the bottles were not secured all the way and caused the leakage. DurationRel: 3 and MitigateEffect: The pkg was quickly taken to our QA team as soon as the pkg was unloaded from the trailer it came from. Our QA team made sure to put it to the side where it would stop leaking and be out of the way from other packages.
